abstract: More on the lost iPhone, Facebook’s open graph and Google doctors.
snippet: More on the lost iPhone, Facebook’s open graph and Google doctors.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times’s tech reporters and editors are seeing reverberations from the lost iPhone prototype story,  mostly from established journalists who are grappling with their feelings toward Apple. But there are other things worth reading too:

headline.main: What We’re Reading: Feelings for Apple

abstract: Topics on this week’s Tech Talk podcast include iFixit.com’s open platform repair manual, Surround Vision from M.I.T.’s Media Lab and a look at in-ear headphones.
snippet: Topics on this week’s Tech Talk podcast include iFixit.com’s open platform repair manual, Surround Vision from M.I.T.’s Media Lab and a look at in-ear headphones.
lead_paragraph: In this week’s Tech Talk podcast, J.D. Biersdorfer explores a new global effort to share information on repairing tech gear. She speaks with Kyle Wiens, a founder of the iFixit Web site, which offers free how-to advice on fixing Apple products. The site has a collaborative repair manual known as Repair 2.0 that aims to reduce electronic waste by enabling people to fix things instead of throwing them away.

headline.main: Tech Talk Podcast: D.I.Y. Electronics Repair

abstract: Siri described its mobile application as a virtual personal assistant, letting users speak commands like “find a table for two” and get answers from the Web.
snippet: Siri described its mobile application as a virtual personal assistant, letting users speak commands like “find a table for two” and get answers from the Web.
lead_paragraph: Apple continued its migration into Google’s turf on Wednesday with the acquisition of Siri, a mobile application that allows users to perform Web searches by voice command on a cellphone.

headline.main: Apple Buys a Start-Up for Its Voice Technology
headline.print_headline: Apple Buys A Start-Up For Its Voice Technology

abstract: Steven P. Jobs, Apple’s chief executive, posted a 1,700-word note on Apple’s site explaining his thoughts on Adobe Flash and the iPhone operating system.
snippet: Steven P. Jobs, Apple’s chief executive, posted a 1,700-word note on Apple’s site explaining his thoughts on Adobe Flash and the iPhone operating system.
lead_paragraph: 9:40 a.m. | Updated  Added response to Apple’s letter from Adobe.

headline.main: Thoughts From Steve Jobs on Flash
